NewWords.WordPhrase: n. skill; successful completion 本领，技艺；完成，成就
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Among her accomplishments were sewing, cooking, playing the piano and dancing.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 成就；成绩
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Flying across the Atlantic for the first time was a great achievement.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 动作；行动
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We must take action before it is too late.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 活动，行动
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He has many activities that take up his time when he's not working.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a short amusing story about a particular person or event 趣闻，轶事
vi. 适用；申请
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The new pension arrangements won't apply to people born before 1960.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. relating to art 艺术的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She draws and paints -- she's very artistic.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. help 帮助
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A team of nurses assisted the doctor in performing the operation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. fasten or join (one thing to another) 系，贴，连接
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Scientists discovered they could measure wind speed by attaching a wind meter to a kite and sending it up.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 服务员；侍者，随从
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Hurry up! The Prince and his attendants will arrive in ten minutes!

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. (fml) wait for 等待，等候
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We must await the results of field studies yet to come.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (cause to) make a sudden loud noise, esp. by hitting two things together 猛敲，猛击
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She always shuts the door with a bang.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. brave and confident 勇敢的，无畏的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It is a bold venture starting a business these days.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. an important event or discovery 突破
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Surgeons have made a great breakthrough in the treatment of heart disease.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. full of busy activity 繁忙的，熙攘的
n. 书法家
ad. awkwardly and ungracefully 笨拙地   clumsy a.
a. that can be compared with sth. 比得上的；可比的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A comparable car would cost far more abroad.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. happening again and again, repeated 不断的，一再重复的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The construction of the airport continued despite continual complaints from local residents.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. v. 对比
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She contrasted the situation then with the present crisis.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. skill, esp. with one's hand 手艺；工艺
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Bill is an expert in the craft of bookbinding.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. resulting from newness of thought 独创的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She's very creative; she writes and paints.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the ability to make new things 创造力
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This job requires creativity as well as communication ability.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. very important; very serious or dangerous 至关重要的；危急的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Environmentalists say a critical factor in the city's pollution is its population.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 文化
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He has studied the cultures of Oriental countries for many years.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. action different from (what is usual or expected); an act of leaving 背离；出发，离开
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I saw Simon shortly before his departure for Russia.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. worth wanting 值得向往的；称心的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I envy Jane because her job is so desirable.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. 有效地  effective a.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Though a few rebels still held out, the fighting was effectively ended.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. come out 出现
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The postman emerged from his van soaked to the skin.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. extremely large 巨大的；极大的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Catherine inherited an enormous fortune from her parents.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (cause to) develop gradually（使）逐步发展
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The story evolves into a violent tragedy.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make (sth.) seem larger, better, etc. than it really is 夸大，夸张
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Peter says he's seen "Titanic" at least 20 times but I think he's exaggerating.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 例外
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Normally, parents aren't allowed to sit in on the classes, but in your case we can make an exception.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. 期待地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The crowds waited for the king and his queen to pass expectantly.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. done in order to find out sth. 探索的
a.  very great 极度的，极端的  n.  the furthest possible limit, an extreme degree 极端，过分
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The girls were afraid of snakes and walked along the mountain trail with extreme caution.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (fml) ability to do sth. easily and well；(pl) equipment, aids, etc. which make it easy to do things 熟练，灵巧；设备，设施
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A free bus to the airport is a facility offered only by this hotel.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (fml) afraid 害怕的，担心的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. What a fearful waste of money!

NewWords.WordPhrase: reach a destination naturally; arrive at 到达；进入，流入
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Shanghai is not an easy city to find your way around.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. help the growth and development of 培养
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We fostered the young girl while her mother was in hospital.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v., n.  皱眉
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He frowned with displeasure as he read his son's school report.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  keep (sth.) secretly in one's mind 怀有
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Shelly harbors a profound hatred towards the man who ruined her life.

NewWords.WordPhrase: at the proper time 在适当时机
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Your book will be published in due course.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 回顾
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The young man knew in retrospect that he should have married his first love Emily.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the state of being free or not controlled by another person, country, etc. 独立；自主
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In 1816, Argentina declared its independence from Spain.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of or at the beginning, first 开始的，最初的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. If a car suddenly pulls out in front of you, your initial reaction may include fear and anger.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (an example of) the introduction of sth. new 革新；新事物
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. For people who hate washing dishes, the dish-washer was a welcome innovation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. impossible to separate from sth. else 不可分离的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The two girls are inseparable friends.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. put, fit, place (in, into, between) 插入，嵌入
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Wait for a couple of minutes with your mouth closed before inserting the thermometer

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 幼儿园
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My daughter is in kindergarten now.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （旅馆的）大堂，（公共场所入口处的）大厅
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I will be waiting for you at the lobby.

NewWords.WordPhrase: repay with sth. good, compensate for 补偿，弥补
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I didn't travel much when I was younger, but I'm certainly making up for lost time now.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a wrong or wicked act 不端行为
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The man must pay for his own misdeed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make (sth.) into a particular shape or form 塑造
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Parents should mold their children by example.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. give too little attention or care to 忽视
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He gave too much attention to his career, working long hours and neglecting his wife.

NewWords.WordPhrase: not at all
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I am not in the least concerned about her study.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 观察者，观察员
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A casual observer may get the wrong impression.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a particular time when sth. happens 时刻；场合  on occasion now and then 有时，间或
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I was usually the only foreign participant, although on occasion I brought other Americans in as guests.

NewWords.Word: (on the one hand)...on the other hand
NewWords.WordPhrase: 一方面…，另一方面…
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. On the one hand her temper was likely to cause trouble, but on the other hand we needed her expertise.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 新颖；独创性
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They elected Tony, a man of great originality, to be their team leader.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. state too strongly 把…讲得过分，夸大
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. overstate one's case

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of a parent or parents 父的；母的；父母的
n. 表现，行为；演出，表演
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The athlete was awarded $10,000 for his good performance in the Olympics.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (pl phenomena or phenomenons) n. 现象
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Hurricanes are a common phenomenon in this region.

NewWords.WordPhrase: gain; learn 获得；学会
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He picked up quite a lot of English during his one-year stay in America.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (rather fml) main, chief 主要的，首要的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The couple's principal concern is to earn enough money to send their children to school.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. sth. that one must do before anything else; sth. that holds a high place among competing claims 优先考虑的事；重点
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Being a qualified teacher is her first priority.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. help to grow or develop 促进，推进
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You don't have to sacrifice environmental protection to promote economic growth.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. look after until fully grown up 养育，抚养
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My grandparents reared ten children.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. directly connected with the subject 有关的，切题的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Only a few people feel the debate about the cloning of human beings is relevant to their daily lives.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. dependence 依靠，依赖
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His reliance on drugs is bad for his health.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a complete change of order, direction, or position 颠倒
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. That would be reversal of the order of host and guest.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. acting without asking for support from others 依靠自己，自力更生
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. self-reliance and hard struggle

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. 轻微地   slight a.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. One of his legs was slightly wounded in the war.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (the act of finding) an answer to a problem 解决（问题的办法）；解答
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There are no simple solutions to the problem of overpopulation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. to some degree, a little 有点，稍微
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It is reported that conditions in the village have improved somewhat since November.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 全体职工，全体雇员
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The hotel has got a staff of about 100.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. manner of doing things 行为方式，风格
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The book is written in a clear easy style.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make a short account of the main points (of sth.) 总结，概述
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Basically, the article can be summarized in three sentences.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. better than average or than others of the same type 优良的；较好的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Long-term stock market investments have produced superior returns compared with cash deposits.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. 同情地  sympathetic a.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. "How is the project going?" The new manager asked sympathetically.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. impressive; effective 难忘的；有力的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Jenny was absorbed at once when she read the most telling passage in that novel.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. young; gentle and loving 年幼的；温柔的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The beef is really tender.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 传统
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It has become a tradition in our family to stay up all night at New Year.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. based on truth or sound reasoning 有根据的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They put forward many valid reasons for not building the skyscraper.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. (fml) regard, consider 看待，考虑
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. How do you view what has just happened?

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. energetically 用力地；精力充沛地  vigorous a.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. To our surprise, the old man walks upstairs vigorously.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. having good intentions 好意的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. a well-intentioned but clumsy waiter

NewWords.WordPhrase: 从事于
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Sophia needs to work at/on her typing speed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. worth doing, worth the trouble taken 值得的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It might be worthwhile to consider buying an insurance policy.
